Violation_Type: Non-compliance with residency requirement in foreign adoption
Legal_Issue: Validity of Ghanaian adoption order under Ghanaian law and Canadian recognition
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) s.117(3)(d)
Application_Facts: Applicant adopted her niece in Ghana but did not meet the residency requirement for adoption under Ghanaian law
Decision_Outcome: IAD initially invalidated the adoption; court set aside IAD decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of IAD decision, redetermination by new panel
Court_Ruling: Canadian authorities cannot override a valid foreign court order without proof of fraud
Claimant_Status: Adoptive parent seeking permanent residency for adopted child
Defendant_Behavior: Visa officer refused permanent residency based on alleged invalid adoption
Grounds_for_Claim: Adoption order was validly issued by Ghanaian court; no evidence of fraud
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in judicial review of administrative decisions
Assessment_Factor: Compliance with local adoption laws in country of origin
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division (IAD) decision
Evidence_Used: Ghanaian adoption order, legal analysis of Ghanaian adoption law
Application_Basis: Permanent residency application based on family sponsorship
Evidence_Assessed: Validity of foreign adoption order, compliance with Ghanaian law
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency for adopted child, quashing of IAD decision
Governing_Rule: Foreign court orders are presumed valid unless proven fraudulent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence of fraud in the Ghanaian adoption process
Outcome: Application allowed, IAD decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Risk of separation between adoptive parent and child due to immigration refusal
Cause_Description: Visa officer refused permanent residency due to alleged non-compliance with Ghanaian adoption laws
Evidence_Handling: IAD failed to respect presumption of validity of foreign court order
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; IRPR s.117(3)(d) requires compliance, but foreign order presumed valid
Evidence_Issues: Presumption of validity of foreign judgments vs. domestic assessment of foreign law compliance
Residency_Compliance: Applicant did not meet Ghanaian residency requirement for adoption
Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian authorities' ability to challenge validity of foreign adoption orders
Evidence_Assessment: Court emphasized need for fraud to challenge foreign adoption
Decision_Rationale: Without proof of fraud, Canadian authorities must recognize valid foreign adoption orders
Evidentiary_Issues: Weight given to foreign court decisions in absence of fraud
